deliberation: I checked the temporal and geographical markers (thirtieth year, fifth day, among the exiles, by the river) and found them literal. The potentially figurative expressions are “the heavens opened” and “I saw visions of God.” The latter functions as a technical term for prophetic experience rather than a metaphor. “The heavens opened” uses a concrete action verb (open) applied to the sky to denote the onset of revelation, which is figurative.

deliberation: This verse is purely chronological clarification: the fifth year of King Jehoiachin’s exile. No comparisons, personifications, or idiomatic expressions beyond normal dating formulae appear.

I considered the phrases “the word of YHWH came to Ezekiel” and “the hand of YHWH was upon him.” Both are conventional prophetic formulas but still employ figurative language: (1) the abstract ‘word’ is said to come to a person; (2) God is described as having a ‘hand’ that comes upon Ezekiel, signifying power and control. Both are metaphorical and personifying.

deliberation: The storm wind, great cloud, and fire could be taken as literal elements within the vision. The explicitly figurative marker is כְּעֵין (kəʿein) ‘like the appearance of’ in relation to חַשְׁמַל (ḥashmal, glowing metal/amber). That’s a simile comparing the inner radiance to a known visual phenomenon.

deliberation: The verse describes four living creatures and then says they had the ‘likeness/figure of a human’ (דְּמוּת אָדָם). In visionary literature, דְּמוּת marks approximative comparison. Here Ezekiel compares their form to a human form to communicate similarity of shape, functioning like a simile/metaphorical likeness.

deliberation: This verse straightforwardly states numerical features: four faces and four wings per creature. No comparative particles (כ, כמראה), no anthropomorphic extension beyond the creatures themselves, and no idioms. The description remains literal within the visionary framework.

I examined the leg and foot description. Two clear similes occur, marked by כ: (1) feet ‘like a calf’s hoof’; (2) sparkling ‘like the appearance of burnished bronze.’ Both compare the creatures’ features to known physical objects for visual approximation.

deliberation: This verse notes that they had human hands under their wings and that faces and wings were on all four sides. Within the vision, these are presented as literal features of the creatures, not as comparisons or idioms about something else.

I considered the expression “חֹבְרֹת אִשָּׁה אֶל־אֲחוֹתָהּ כַּנְפֵיהֶם” (‘their wings joined one to another’). Though it uses ‘sister’ lexically, it is a standard way to say ‘one to another’ rather than a crafted metaphor. The rest of the verse describes literal movement mechanics. I judge this as descriptive, not figurative.

This catalogs the four faces: human, lion, ox, eagle, on different sides. In context, these are literal components of the visionary beings, not explicit similes or metaphors applied to another subject. Symbolic significance aside, the language itself is straightforward description, not figurative comparison.

The verse details the arrangement of wings: two touching, two covering the bodies. No comparative particle is used and no non-creaturely subject is being described. It is literal structural description of the beings’ posture.

The motion of each creature ‘in the direction of its face’ and ‘wherever the spirit would go’ is presented straightforwardly. While ‘spirit’ can have rich theological meaning, here it labels the animating principle guiding their movement, not a figurative expression describing something else. No similes or metaphors are explicit.

This verse contains explicit comparison markers: כְּגַחֲלֵי־אֵשׁ (‘like burning coals of fire’) and כְּמַרְאֵה הַלַּפִּדִים (‘like the appearance of torches’). Both are similes used to describe something moving among the creatures. The radiance and lightning issuing from the fire are then described literally within the vision.

deliberation: This verse simply introduces wheels on the earth beside each creature. It is spatial description without comparative particles, idioms, or anthropomorphic extensions beyond the visionary elements themselves.

deliberation: The movement of the wheels toward the four quarters and their not turning is straightforward mechanical description. No figurative comparisons or idioms beyond literal technical detailing.

The rims being high and fearsome and full of eyes is part of the literal content of the vision. While symbolically suggestive (omniscience), the text itself does not use ‘eyes’ metaphorically for perception or knowledge; it simply reports what was seen.

Describes the coordinated movement of wheels and creatures. All elements (going, being lifted) are narrative of the vision; there is no separate target domain being described by analogy, and no explicit comparative particles.

Reiterates that the wheels move wherever the spirit goes, since the spirit of the living beings is in the wheels. This is mystical but not linguistically figurative in the sense of simile/metaphor about a different target; it explains the linkage internal to the vision. No explicit figurative markers are present.
Again describes synchronized motion and stillness of wheels and creatures. The phraseology is repetitive and purely descriptive of mechanics; no ‘like/as’ comparisons or idiomatic metaphors appear.
